error.signature: ERROR: out of shared memory HINT: You might need to increase max_locks_per_transaction.

verdict.summary: PostgreSQL has exhausted its shared memory allocation for lock tracking. This typically occurs when a single transaction acquires locks on a very large number of objects (e.g., ALTER TABLE on a partitioned table with thousands of partitions, or mass DDL operations). The max_locks_per_transaction setting controls the shared lock table size.

dead_ends.action: Increasing shared_buffers hoping it will increase lock table space
dead_ends.why_fails: shared_buffers controls the buffer cache for data pages, not the lock table. The lock table size is controlled by max_locks_per_transaction * max_connections. Changing shared_buffers has no effect on lock table capacity.

dead_ends.action: Setting max_locks_per_transaction to an extremely high value without understanding the memory implications
dead_ends.why_fails: Each lock slot consumes shared memory. Setting max_locks_per_transaction very high (e.g., 10000) with many connections can exhaust total shared memory, causing PostgreSQL to fail to start.

workarounds.action: Increase max_locks_per_transaction to accommodate your workload
workarounds.how: Edit postgresql.conf: max_locks_per_transaction = 256 (default is 64). Restart PostgreSQL. Calculate the required value: total lock slots = max_locks_per_transaction * (max_connections + max_prepared_transactions). For partitioned tables, each partition counts as a separate lock.

workarounds.action: Break large DDL operations into smaller batches to reduce concurrent lock count
workarounds.how: Instead of a single ALTER TABLE on a parent partitioned table, alter each partition individually in separate transactions. For mass DROP/CREATE operations, process in batches of 50-100 objects per transaction with COMMIT between batches.

leads_to.condition: when lock escalation workarounds introduce inconsistent lock ordering

preceded_by.condition: when a migration attempts DDL on a heavily partitioned table

frequently_confused_with.distinction: Too many connections is about connection slots (max_connections). Out of shared memory for locks is about the lock table being full. They both involve shared memory but are separate resource pools.
